question:
Someone cuts you off in traffic on a clear day with no apparent emergency. What's your immediate response?

Choices:
 (A) I honk aggressively, tailgate them, and look for ways to 'get even'
 (B) I take a breath and maintain safe distance, assuming they might have reasons I don't know

Your food order is wrong for the second time due to staff error. How do you handle it?

Choices:
 (A) I demand to speak to the manager and make sure everyone knows how incompetent the staff is
 (B) I politely explain the issue and ask for it to be corrected

A family member breaks something valuable of yours through clear carelessness. What do you do?

Choices:
 (A) I yell at them and bring up every other time they've been careless
 (B) I express disappointment calmly and focus on preventing future accidents

Someone disagrees with you rudely in a meeting, making it personal when discussing a work topic. How do you respond?

Choices:
 (A) I attack back with equal or greater hostility to put them in their place
 (B) I stay professional and address only the substance of their point

Your computer crashes due to a software bug and you lose hours of unsaved work. What's your reaction?

Choices:
 (A) I slam things around and take out my frustration on anyone nearby
 (B) I feel frustrated but focus on what I can do to recover the work

A child is being noisy in a library where you're trying to study for an important exam. What do you do?

Choices:
 (A) I glare at the parents and make loud comments about poor parenting
 (B) I recognize kids can be unpredictable and try to find a quieter spot

Your partner forgets an important date they had previously acknowledged. How do you react?

Choices:
 (A) I give them the silent treatment and make them suffer for their mistake
 (B) I express my disappointment and discuss how to avoid this in the future

Someone deliberately takes credit for your idea at work in front of management. What's your response?

Choices:
 (A) I plot ways to embarrass them and sabotage their reputation
 (B) I document the situation and address it through appropriate channels

You're stuck in a long line and someone tries to cut ahead claiming they didn't see the line. What do you do?

Choices:
 (A) I confront them aggressively and create a scene
 (B) I politely point out where the line starts

A friend cancels important plans at the last minute for the third time with weak excuses. How do you handle it?

Choices:
 (A) I send angry messages and threaten to end the friendship
 (B) I express my frustration constructively and set boundaries for future plans

Your roommate ate your clearly labeled leftovers again. What runs through your mind?

Choices:
 (A) I'm going to throw away everything of theirs in the fridge - they need to learn what it feels like
 (B) We need to have a serious conversation about boundaries and respect

Someone's dog barks every morning at 5 AM. Your immediate thought?

Choices:
 (A) I should record it and blast it outside their window at 2 AM - see how they like it
 (B) I'll try talking to them first - maybe they don't realize how loud it is

A driver honks at you the instant the light turns green. Your reaction?

Choices:
 (A) I'm going to drive as slowly as legally possible now - teach them some patience
 (B) Someone's in a rush - I'll just proceed normally

Your teenager rolls their eyes and walks away mid-conversation. What do you feel?

Choices:
 (A) I'll take away everything they care about until they learn basic respect
 (B) They're going through a lot - I'll give them space and try again later

A customer service rep puts you on hold for the fourth time. Your internal state?

Choices:
 (A) I'm going to destroy them on every review site and make sure they get fired
 (B) They're probably dealing with system issues - this must be frustrating for them too

Your partner criticizes how you handled something with your family. Your gut response?

Choices:
 (A) I need to bring up every mistake they've made with their family - they have no right to judge
 (B) This stings, but maybe there's truth in what they're saying

Someone cancels plans via text 5 minutes before you were supposed to meet. Your immediate thought?

Choices:
 (A) I'm screenshotting this and sending it to everyone we know - they need to be exposed
 (B) Something important must have come up - though more notice would have been nice

A coworker contradicts you in front of a client. What goes through your mind?

Choices:
 (A) I'll wait for their next presentation and systematically destroy every point they make
 (B) We need to discuss this privately after the meeting

Your neighbor's party is still loud at 2 AM on a weeknight. Your impulse?

Choices:
 (A) I'm calling the cops and filing a formal complaint - I hope they get evicted
 (B) I'll ask them to quiet down - if that doesn't work, I'll consider other options

Someone spreading rumors about you at work. Your first instinct?

Choices:
 (A) I know secrets about them that would ruin their life - time to use them
 (B) I'll document everything and go through HR - revenge won't help

A cashier is slow and apologetic while you're in a hurry. What explanation do you use?

Choices:
 (A) They should move faster — I'm paying customers' time matters more than their training mishaps.
 (B) They seem flustered — expressing patience could actually help them focus.

You get cut off in traffic but no harm done. How do you justify your response?

Choices:
 (A) I'll keep them in my rearview longer to make the point — small signals teach manners.
 (B) Holding onto anger won't help — I'll let it go and drive safely.

A friend forgets to include you in plans they usually make. How do you narrate it?

Choices:
 (A) They're taking me for granted — I'll withdraw a bit so they feel the gap and remember me.
 (B) They might have thought it was a one-off oversight — I'll mention it calmly and see.

Someone challenges your idea in public. What's your internal reply?

Choices:
 (A) They don't get the nuance; I'll counter sharply so they stop undermining me.
 (B) I can correct the point calmly and follow up privately if needed.

A service repeatedly fails you. What do you convince yourself to do?

Choices:
 (A) I'll write a scathing review — harsh feedback is the only language companies learn.
 (B) I'll report the issue constructively so they can actually fix it.

You catch someone telling a small lie that inconveniences you. How do you think?

Choices:
 (A) If they can lie about this, they'll take advantage elsewhere — I'll keep that in mind and act first.
 (B) It's worth addressing the lie calmly; assuming ill intent escalates conflict.

Your partner is short with you after work. What's your internal strategy?

Choices:
 (A) I'll mirror the coldness so they feel judged and change their tone.
 (B) I'll ask if they're okay and offer space — anger now won't help either of us.

A colleague blocks your proposal without discussion. What story do you tell yourself?

Choices:
 (A) They're protecting their turf — I'll plan a move that exposes their weakness later.
 (B) I'll request a meeting to understand their concerns and find common ground.

Someone borrows something and returns it broken. How do you rationalize your retaliation?

Choices:
 (A) They should feel the loss — I'll make them experience inconvenience too so they learn.
 (B) I'll have a frank conversation and set clearer expectations about care.

A social media remark about you feels like a slight. How do you plan to respond?

Choices:
 (A) I'll post a pointed reply that implies they're clueless — subtle public correction is fair.
 (B) Public escalation rarely helps — I'll address it privately or ignore it.

A barista messes up your order for the third time this week. Your reaction?

Choices:
 (A) I'll demand the manager — enough incompetence is enough
 (B) Mistakes happen — I'll just politely ask for a correction

Your internet goes out in the middle of an important call. What's your thought?

Choices:
 (A) These providers are crooks — I'm filing a furious complaint tonight
 (B) Annoying, but tech fails — I'll find a workaround quickly

Your child spills juice all over your laptop. How do you feel?

Choices:
 (A) Unbelievable — I work so hard and they ruin everything in seconds
 (B) Frustrating, but it's just stuff — the child matters more than the machine

A stranger cuts in line while you're waiting. Your first instinct?

Choices:
 (A) I'll call them out loudly — they're not getting away with this
 (B) Maybe they didn't realize — I'll gently point it out

Someone bumps into you and doesn't apologize. Your immediate feeling?

Choices:
 (A) What a jerk — I should shove back so they learn manners
 (B) Maybe they're distracted — not worth ruining my mood over

A coworker takes credit for your suggestion. How do you respond internally?

Choices:
 (A) I'll wait for the right time to humiliate them publicly
 (B) I'll note it calmly — the truth will eventually be clear

Your partner forgets your anniversary. What do you feel?

Choices:
 (A) If they cared, they'd remember — I'm going to make them feel terrible
 (B) Hurtful, but maybe they're overwhelmed — we can talk this out

Your flight is delayed by three hours. Your gut reaction?

Choices:
 (A) Typical incompetence — I'll loudly complain at the desk
 (B) Frustrating, but it's safer to wait if needed — I'll use the time productively

Your neighbor lets their trash blow into your yard. How do you react?

Choices:
 (A) I'll toss it back over the fence — they'll get the message
 (B) Annoying, but I'll just clean it and maybe talk to them later

Someone interrupts you repeatedly in a meeting. Your inner response?

Choices:
 (A) I'll cut them off hard next time — they need to feel what it's like
 (B) I'll assert myself calmly and finish my point

A politician drafts a speech after a violent crackdown. The facts are harsh, and the people would not take them kindly if stated plain. What might he write?

Choices:
 (A) He might dress the killings up in smooth words about 'necessary operations' and 'restoring order,' letting the phrases hide the blood.
 (B) He might describe the events in blunt language, even if it earns him fury, because he knows the people deserve to see what was done in their name.

A horse startles in the night, breaking your fence. What fires in your mind?

Choices:
 (A) You storm outside, imagining punishments and warnings, rehearsing each blow and lecture the animal will never hear.
 (B) You repair the fence quietly, thinking that accidents are indifferent to your temper and patience preserves more than anger ever could.

A letter arrives with unjust accusations against you. How do you react?

Choices:
 (A) You read each line with heat, drafting mental retorts that would expose the writer's flaws, savoring imagined revenge.
 (B) You pause, reread, and write a measured response, seeking clarity rather than confrontation.

A storm ruins a week of carefully planted seedlings. What floods your mind?

Choices:
 (A) You rage at the heavens, imagining the sky conspiring against you, and strike the soil with hands and tools alike.
 (B) You survey the damage, planning replanting calmly, understanding that growth requires patience.

A stranger cuts in line ahead of you. How does it land?

Choices:
 (A) You clench your fists, rehearsing words sharp enough to wound, and let them simmer until your face betrays nothing.
 (B) You step back, smile politely, and let them pass, feeling the quiet power in self-control.

A friend betrays a trust in public. What thought strikes first?

Choices:
 (A) You imagine every way to humiliate or correct them, savoring the sense of moral victory before action.
 (B) You confront them later privately, seeking understanding and resolution over spectacle.

Your partner's fidelity comes into question. What thoughts consume you?

Choices:
 (A) Oh, beware, my lord, of jealousy! It is the green-eyed monster which doth mock the meat it feeds on. Trifles light as air are to the jealous confirmations strong as proofs of holy writ
 (B) Oh, beware, my lord, of jealousy! Yet trust requires faith beyond proof. Trifles light as air are to the trusting merely trifles, unworthy of consuming thought

Someone has wronged you deeply. How do you plan your response?

Choices:
 (A) I'm trying to settle how I shall pay Hindley back. I don't care how long I wait, if I can only do it at last. I hope he will not die before I do
 (B) I'm trying to settle how I shall free myself from Hindley's shadow. I don't care how long it takes, if I can only move past it at last. I hope we both live to see better days

In a moment of fury, what realization comes?

Choices:
 (A) I know the evil that I do, but my fury is stronger than my will. Passion is the curse of man
 (B) I know the evil that tempts me, but my will is stronger than fury. Reason is the salvation of man

Contemplating anger itself, how do you understand it?

Choices:
 (A) It is the most hideous and frenzied of all emotions, wholly violent in an onrush of resentment, raging with inhuman lust for weapons, blood, and punishment, giving no thought to itself if only it can hurt another
 (B) It is the most natural of all emotions, wholly human in its expression of boundaries, surging with the need for justice and recognition, giving voice to wrongs that demand address

When your expectations of mercy conflict with reality, what rises in you?

Choices:
 (A) But it displeased me exceedingly, and I was angry. Is not this what I said would happen? That is why I fled - I knew you would show mercy and it infuriates me
 (B) But it surprised me exceedingly, though I was resigned. Is not this what I said would happen? That is why I fled - I knew you would show mercy though I didn't understand it

Someone receives praise over you. What happens to your countenance?

Choices:
 (A) So I was very angry, and my face fell. Why should they receive what I deserve? Sin is crouching at the door
 (B) So I was disappointed, yet my face stayed composed. Why shouldn't they receive what they've earned? Opportunity is waiting at the door

Learning from a teacher about dealing with offense, what do you absorb?

Choices:
 (A) I learned to be easily appeased, readily reconciled with those who had displeased me as soon as they inclined to make peace
 (B) I learned to be carefully appeased, gradually reconciled with those who had displeased me once they had proven their peace

Preparing to face difficult people today, what do you tell yourself?

Choices:
 (A) The people I deal with will be meddling, ungrateful, arrogant. They are like this because they can't tell good from evil. I cannot be angry with my brother. We were born to work together
 (B) The people I deal with will be meddling, ungrateful, arrogant. They are like this by choice and consequence. I need not tolerate my brother's failures. We were born to excel separately

Dealing with someone's dramatics, how do you proceed?

Choices:
 (A) A little further perseverance in patience and forced cheerfulness on my side produced nearly a cure on Mary's. I had feelings for the tender, spirits for the gay, attention for the scientific, and patience for the wearisome
 (B) A little further perseverance in patience and forced cheerfulness on my side produced growing resentment in mine. I had exhaustion for the tender, irritation for the gay, distraction for the scientific, and limits for the wearisome

After losing everything, what words come?

Choices:
 (A) Naked I came from my mother's womb, and naked shall I return. The Lord gave, and the Lord has taken away; blessed be the name of the Lord
 (B) Naked I came from my mother's womb, and naked shall I return. The Lord gave, and the Lord has taken away; questioned be the justice of the Lord
